title: i guess its ok
comment: im not sure there is any real point unless theres a device too stupid to know when a new file was added and automatically count it in the list (sounds like some devices werent thought up carefully but whatever).  as for my device anytime a new file is added its automatically counted,  which is odd for a piece of garbage device like mine.  the external storage is auto-scanned anyway upon mounting so this app seems pointless to me,   but it is fun to goof off with so ill give that much.   in any case my only problem is that despite specifying the directory (external) it still scans the internal.  but it also scans the external as well.  now if we can get it to only scan the specified and not the other as well (if the file path is /sdcard0 it should only scan sdcard0,  if its sdcard1 to only scan sdcard1 - not both).  also we should also be allowed to not put /storage/ or /mnt/ before ....  if i want to only put /sdcard0/  it should scan even though /storage/ wasnt added.  the reason is because it should already know the /storage/ (or /mnt/) part so we shouldnt have to specify that in the directory.  just where its going from there.

title: Not functional on Droid RAZR Maxx HD
comment: After Verizon updated my Droid RAZR Maxx HD phone to KitKat, I like many others lost the ability to play mp3 files and other media on my SDcard with players like "Play Music" from the My Library.  Was hopeful that this app would fix that w/o having to root the phone, which I should probably do anyways. The app appears to scan the external SDcard okay, but then the My Library in media players still does not see the media on the SDCard. There is some indication that after the scan that the app stops running.

title: Nice
comment: Only one that works for Kit Kat

title: only media rescanner to work on kitkat
comment: I tried maybe 7 other media rescanners and they would all crash. This one actually works because it's made with KitKat's new restrictions in mind.  One internet user wrote this "Because lots of apps abused the MEDIA_MOUNTED broadcast intent to cause a rescan of the whole filesystem (draining battery) after they only changed one file, KitKat has a new restriction that only system apps can broadcast this intent. Apps that try will get a SecurityException, which by default causes the "... has stopped" dialog."
Works. Also, it's ad- and clutter-free.
Solves Android problems

title: Best media scanner app
comment: I moved my folders to external SD with Folder Mount app, but the gallery couldn't see the files, and wouldn't refresh on boot. This app, the only one that worked without FC, took a few minutes and worked exactly as required. Only thing I would suggest is the ability to visually navigate to your external folder, as I couldn't remember the exact path, which Folder Mount does exceptionally well.

title: CAUTION
comment: After using this app, /storage directory is DIRECTLY EXPOSED to the PC in the 'Internal Storage' while connected via MTP. Deleting this folder will WIPE OUT ENTIRE INTERNAL STORAGE, AS WELL AS THE EXTERNAL SD CARD. Also sometimes 'system' is exposed too. AVOID ANYTHING LABELED 'storage', or 'system', do not delete them, do not even touch them.  However this app really does what it claimed to do.

title: Pretty handy
comment: My phone decided it didn't want to remember where my audio files were. I had lost the links to not just my music, but my ringtones, alarms and notifications. I tried some other media scanners and this is the only one that worked for me. The only drawback is you have to type in the path you want to scan, which I found using Root Explorer. If it had a file browser and an option to scan my entire device, I would give this 5 stars.

Choosing a path or directory to update should have a more friendly interface, now you have to write the path manually.

title: Autorun option?
comment: Thanks for this, Jeremy...people like you and this kind of little app (30kb, no permissions) are examples of what makes Android great.  I know this might not be the right venue for a feature request, but here I go anyhow: I'd love to be able to summon your app from Tasker, so that I can use my 'file copy' script and then have it call the app to refresh the desired folder.  Tasker will 'open' an app, is there any chance that you can give us an option to automatically run a scan on the provided folder on launch (and then maybe close?).  Regardless, thanks for your selfless efforts here and a great little app!

comment: I had some issues with my nfs mounted drive, causing SD Scanner to crash, but Jeremy provided me a new version within 2 hours, which works seamless now.  Great app, simple, does what it has to do! Worth 6* :-)

title: Great app
comment: It's the only one that worked on my nexus 4 with android 4.4 . This sd scan bug is really a shame. I can't believe that Google still hasn't fixed it.

title: Fixed music duplicates
comment: I sftp'ed music files to my Nexus 5 and my Android Music Player was showing duplicate, non-functioning files. All the older media scanning apps crashed but this one did the job after emptying my media caches.

title: Excellent work!
comment: I don't usually review apps but this deserves the appreciation! Using the work around this app works like charm!

title: You rock!!!
comment: I might be some weird edge case, but this is exactly what I was looking for since I updated to KitKat. I would DL videos then hook it up to my Pc to watch and they would never be there without a refresh, all the old apps broke and you are the first to fix it (as far as I know) the only other way to refresh was rebooting the device which was pretty annoying, this app is great/no nonsense

title: Works perfectly.
comment: This works perfectly. After seeing a reference to the changed interface in KitKat, I was afraid I was going to have to write a program exactly like this myself. But you beat me to it. Well done.  Good on you for making it GPL. Please put an identical donate version in the market, or provide a donate link.  Tested on 2012 Nexus 7, KitKat build KRT16S.

title: Works great with my Nexus 5
comment: Thanks a ton. Works great. One question though - How do I tell the app to scan only a specific subfolder?

You can change the path to check for new files in the text box at the top.  It always scans the whole media database for updated/deleted, because that's much faster than actually scanning files and provides a huge speedup if the new file path contains many up-to-date files.  Is there a reason you need to scan just a subfolder?
works perfectly, exactly what i was looking for
Works great!

title: Exactly what I was looking for!
comment: Perfect app, does exactly what you need.

title: Finally someone figured it out!
comment: Awesome man, you're a genius.

title: Just what I needed
comment: Works great, though a little rough around the edges. Perhaps there could be OI File Manager integration to make it easier to enter paths?

Hopefully some of the rough edges are fixed with the 1.3 release, which I finished before I read your suggestion.  As fast as 1.3 has been for me, I suspect it's faster just to leave the path at the default all the time.  I could even remove the ability to customize it.  What do you think?

title: Good
comment: Thank you for this
